title.narrative: IR 1.PROMOTION DES SIX PRATIQUES FAMILIA

description.narrative: At 31 December 2015 the rate of knowledge of six essential family practices (EFP) aiming to significantly reduce infant mortality has increased by 30% for each of these practices, which contributes to Cross-Sectoral Adolescent Development, Cross-Sectoral Communication For Development, Immunization, Polio Eradication. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By the end of 2015, 40 per cent of men and women adopt the six key family practices (exclusive breastfeeding, sleeping under insecticide-treated mosquito nets, handwashing with soap, treatment of diarrhoea using Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS), Prevention of Mother to Child Transmission of HIV (PMTCT) of HIV, and complementary infant feeding) for child survival and development, with at least a 30 per cent increase in each practice nationwide.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: At 31 December 2015 the rate of knowledge of six essential family practices (EFP) aiming to significantly reduce infant mortalityhas increased by 30% for each of these practices

description.narrative: UNICEF supported increased capacity of Ministry of Health and implementing partners through training of 156 health agents on communication, and 621 community relays, 274 school children and 41 radio communicators on essential family practices (EFP). Interpersonal communication and radio programmes strengthened the knowledge and practices of populations on EFP | Status:Met | As-of Date:31/12/2017
